verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: The LORD continues the direct communication with Moses, affirming his prophetic role.

verses.text: "Take vengeance for the Israelites on the Midianites. Afterward you will be gathered to your people."
verses.comment: "Take vengeance" refers to fulfilling God’s judgment, showing both justice and foreshadowing divine retribution (see Num. 25:17). "Gathered to your people" is a Hebrew idiom for death, emphasizing union with the patriarchs—hinting at the communion of saints.

verses.text: So Moses spoke to the people, saying, "Arm some of your men for war, so that they may go against Midian to carry out the LORD's vengeance on them.
verses.comment: Moses faithfully acts as God’s mediator, revealing obedience as a key theme, prefiguring Christ’s perfect obedience (see Phil. 2:8).

verses.text: Send a thousand men from each of the tribes of Israel into battle."
verses.comment: The formation reflects ordered service and selection from among the people, symbolizing unity and structure in God’s covenant community.

verses.text: So from the thousands of Israel, a thousand from each tribe, twelve thousand men armed for war, were supplied.
verses.comment: The number twelve is significant for the twelve tribes, foreshadowing the apostolic foundation in the New Testament (see Matt. 10:2–4).

verses.text: Moses sent them, a thousand from each tribe, to the war, and along with them, Phinehas son of Eleazar the priest, with the holy vessels and the trumpets for sounding.
verses.comment: Phinehas’ priestly leadership and presence of holy vessels show war was not merely secular but had religious significance, underlining sacramental mediation in crucial moments.

verses.text: They fought against Midian, as the LORD commanded Moses, and killed every man.
verses.comment: Total victory by divine command. The severity reflects both historical and allegorical lessons on sin’s consequences.

verses.text: They killed the kings of Midian with the rest of their slain—Evi, Rekem, Zur, Hur, and Reba, the five kings of Midian. They also killed Balaam son of Beor with the sword.
verses.comment: Balaam's death fulfills judgment on false prophecy; his story warns against pursuing personal gain over truth (see 2 Pet. 2:15).

verses.text: The Israelites captured the women of Midian and their children, and took all their livestock, all their flocks, and all their goods as plunder.
verses.comment: Plunder as part of the spoils aligns with ancient custom but also points to deeper spiritual dispossession and renewal.

verses.text: They burned all the cities where the Midianites lived, and all their encampments.
verses.comment: Complete destruction was required; such themes prefigure the cleansing of sin and establishment of holiness.

verses.text: They took all the spoil and all the plunder, both people and animals.
verses.comment: Distinction between spoil and plunder underscores ordered stewardship and distribution.

verses.text: They brought the captives, the plunder, and the spoil to Moses, to Eleazar the priest, and to the assembly of the Israelites at the camp in the plains of Moab by the Jordan across from Jericho.
verses.comment: The inclusion of the priest and assembly in the distribution points to priestly mediation and the structure of God’s people, showing ordered authority within the covenant community.

verses.text: Moses, Eleazar the priest, and all the leaders of the congregation went to meet them outside the camp.
verses.comment: Meeting outside the camp suggests concerns for ritual purity and separation, anticipating later sacramental distinctions.

verses.text: Moses was angry with the officers of the army, the commanders of thousands and the commanders of hundreds, who returned from battle.
verses.comment: Moses’ anger reveals the seriousness of God's command and expectation of obedience, highlighting the consequences of divergence from divine instruction.

verses.text: Moses said to them, "Have you kept all the women alive?
verses.comment: Preserving the women disregarded divine command, since they were enticers to idolatry, a spiritual danger prefiguring temptations addressed by Christ.

verses.text: "Look, these women caused the Israelites, through the counsel of Balaam, to act treacherously against the LORD in the matter of Peor, and so plague came upon the LORD's community.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the role of Balaam and the consequences of idolatry and immorality, directly linking spiritual unfaithfulness to communal suffering—a key principle for sanctity.

verses.text: So now, kill every male among the little ones, and kill every woman who has known man intimately.
verses.comment: The command has historical severity but allegorically points to the thoroughness of spiritual purification and repentance.

verses.text: But keep alive for yourselves all the young girls who have not known a man intimately.
verses.comment: Selective preservation, echoing patterns of mercy and new community formation, symbolizing the renewal of Israel.

verses.text: "All of you who killed anyone or touched a dead body, stay outside the camp for seven days. Purify yourselves and your captives on the third day and on the seventh day.
verses.comment: Ritual uncleanness required specific purification rites, reinforcing the liturgical cycle central to Israel’s relationship with God.

verses.text: Purify every garment, everything made of leather, everything made of goat’s hair, and every object made of wood."
verses.comment: The extent of ritual purification includes even materials associated with uncleanness, signifying holistic sanctification.

verses.text: Then Eleazar the priest said to the men of war who had gone to battle, "This is the statute of the law which the LORD commanded Moses:
verses.comment: Eleazar’s role as priest reveals the necessity of priestly mediation in interpreting and applying divine law, prefiguring New Testament authority structures.

verses.text: "Only the gold, silver, bronze, iron, tin, and lead,
verses.comment: Enumeration of metals highlights ritual laws for purity, preparation for sanctuary use, and echoes the sanctification of material creation.

verses.text: everything that can withstand fire, you must make it go through fire, and it will be clean—but it must also be purified with the water for purification. Whatever cannot withstand fire, you must make go through water.
verses.comment: Combination of fire and water for purification foreshadows the sacraments of baptism and spiritual cleansing (see John 3:5).

verses.text: On the seventh day wash your clothes; then you will be clean. Afterward you may come into the camp."
verses.comment: Seventh day purification aligns with the Sabbath principle of completion. Entry into camp represents restored communion.

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: The continued speaking of the LORD shows ongoing revelation and guidance through chosen leaders.

verses.text: "Take the census of the plunder captured, both of the people and animals, you and Eleazar the priest and the chiefs of the fathers’ houses of the congregation.
verses.comment: The census marks stewardship and responsibility, shared with priestly leadership and family heads, signaling collaboration in governance.

verses.text: Divide the plunder between the warriors who went out to battle and all the congregation.
verses.comment: Equitable distribution shows unity and corporate benefit, prefiguring the spiritual treasures distributed throughout the Church.

verses.text: And levy a tribute for the LORD from the warriors who went out to battle: one out of every five hundred, both of the people, cattle, donkeys, and sheep.
verses.comment: Offering a tribute to the LORD from the spoils underscores the principle of firstfruits and ongoing sacrificial giving.

verses.text: Take it from their half and give it to Eleazar the priest as a contribution to the LORD.
verses.comment: Offerings given through the priest signify mediation and the importance of the priesthood in representing the people to God.

verses.text: And from the half belonging to the Israelites, take one out of every fifty, of the people, cattle, donkeys, and sheep, and give them to the Levites, who keep charge of the LORD’s tabernacle.
verses.comment: Special provision for Levites reflects their perpetual service and underscores the necessity of supporting sacred ministers.

verses.text: Moses and Eleazar the priest did as the LORD commanded Moses.
verses.comment: Obedience without hesitation provides a model of faithfulness and submission to God’s word.

verses.text: The total spoil, apart from what the warriors had taken, was 675,000 sheep,
verses.comment: Wealth and numbers emphasize God’s blessing and provision, reminiscent of Abraham’s flocks and the abundance given to God’s people.

verses.text: 72,000 cattle,
verses.comment: Large numbers signify God’s favor and the material blessings poured out for faithful perseverance.

verses.text: 61,000 donkeys,
verses.comment: Abundance of animals, including donkeys, shows economic strength and readiness for future journey or service.

verses.text: and 32,000 people in all, women who had not known a man intimately.
verses.comment: 32,000 is a significant number, showing the scale of integration and raising questions of mercy and assimilation.

verses.text: The half that belonged to those who fought in the battle numbered: 337,500 sheep,
verses.comment: Half-division demonstrates equity and the meticulous stewardship in fulfilling God’s directives for both spiritual and material treasures.

verses.text: and the LORD’s tribute from the sheep was 675.
verses.comment: A precise accounting honors God’s portion and develops the theme of sacrificial giving and stewardship.

verses.text: The cattle numbered 36,000, of which the LORD’s tribute was 72.
verses.comment: Even in details, the sanctification of the offering is reinforced; nothing is too small for dedication to God.

verses.text: The donkeys numbered 30,500; the LORD’s tribute was 61.
verses.comment: Significance of tribute persists across all types of property, reinforcing comprehensive stewardship.

verses.text: The people were 16,000; the LORD’s tribute was 32 souls.
verses.comment: Sacrificial offering even among persons shows the seriousness of consecrated service and underscores the value of every soul set apart.

verses.text: Moses gave the tribute, the LORD’s offering, to Eleazar the priest, as the LORD had commanded Moses.
verses.comment: Priestly mediation in the distribution of tribute reflects God’s means of sanctifying offerings through appointed leadership.

verses.text: From the Israelites’ half, which Moses separated from that of the warriors,
verses.comment: The division between warriors and congregation maintains justice and charity toward all members.

verses.text: (now the congregation's half was 337,500 sheep,
verses.comment: Continues the precise accounting, emphasizing stewardship and transparency.

verses.text: 36,000 cattle,
verses.comment: Half of the total cattle, maintaining fairness and reflecting divine consistency.

verses.text: 30,500 donkeys,
verses.comment: Half of the donkeys, following God’s prescribed division.

verses.text: and 16,000 people),
verses.comment: Completes the record of the congregation’s share, showing inclusive provision for all.

verses.text: Moses took one out of every fifty, both of people and animals, from the Israelites’ half, and gave them to the Levites, who kept charge of the LORD's tabernacle, as the LORD commanded Moses.
verses.comment: Support of the Levites for their tabernacle service reinforces dependence on sacred ministers for spiritual welfare.

verses.text: Then the officers who were over the thousands of the army, the commanders of thousands and the commanders of hundreds, approached Moses;
verses.comment: Leaders from the warriors acknowledge Moses’ authority and present themselves with humility and accountability.

verses.text: and they said to Moses, "Your servants have counted the warriors under our command, and not one of us is missing.
verses.comment: Not one missing: a miracle of preservation, showing that God can preserve those faithfully engaged in His work.

verses.text: So we have brought an offering to the LORD, what each man found: articles of gold—armlets, bracelets, signet rings, earrings, and necklaces—to make atonement for ourselves before the LORD."
verses.comment: Voluntary offerings for atonement show a deep concern for spiritual purity, prefiguring sacrificial atonement fulfilled in Christ’s priestly work (Hebrews 9:11-14).

verses.text: Moses and Eleazar the priest received the gold from them, all crafted ornaments.
verses.comment: Acceptance by Moses and Eleazar further highlights the role of priestly mediation, which is a recurring biblical theme.

verses.text: All the gold from the offering that the commanders brought for the LORD weighed 16,750 shekels.
verses.comment: Generosity in offerings illustrates the principle of giving back to God from the abundance received.

verses.text: The men of war had taken spoil, each for himself.
verses.comment: Personal share highlights individual responsibility while communal offering upholds collective consecration.

verses.text: Moses and Eleazar the priest received the gold from the commanders and brought it into the Tent of Meeting as a memorial for the Israelites before the LORD.
verses.comment: The memorial offering kept before the LORD in the tent shows the lasting nature of sacrifice and the importance of sacred remembrance within the community, resonating with the continual offering seen later in Scriptural tradition.
